message:
it's just sad to not see Arabic on the left
the whole internet is talking about this bug now
and that what we know about heartbleed 
http://goo.gl/3B1B1Z
http://goo.gl/sEI3qq
name: Heartbleed - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
caption: en.wikipedia.org

data.message: If that's something that concerns you, what stops you from entering some content in an arabic page for it? Maybe even find some arabic content and copy from it (citing it in the references section a the only reference).
Just being sad about something doesn't change it.

i can do that in other fields, and i'm doing it sometimes
but security, it will have a lot of phrases and idioms i can't translate

If you are interested in covering the topic, you can use some of these random references
https://www.google.com.eg/search?q=open+ssl+arabic&rlz=1C1OPRB_enAU579AU579&oq=open+ssl+arabic&aqs=chrome..69i57.5237j0j7&sourceid=chrome&es_sm=93&ie=UTF-8#lr=lang_ar&q=openssl+heart+bleed+ssl&tbs=lr:lang_1ar
This is a translation of one of the popular articles on the topic http://www.tech-wd.com/wd/2014/04/13/%D8%AB%D8%BA%D8%B1%D8%A9-heartbleed/

ok, this is good
the lack of news about this just remind me how much translation is important
if you looked on the English websites you will find not just programmer care about this, but almost all the internet users there
and the users here don't know about it because it didn't spread in arabic
the article on tech-wd is great, but that don't mean we are following up as much as we should
I think it's not lack of translation. It's more how different the IT culture is, and how few our dependencies on IT are. That's a big topic anyway.

To explain what I mean, if newspapers thought that this was a topic that would affect most people, they would try to cover the topic. The thing is, all IT press is specialized (targeted to professionals and gamers), because the technology is not yet a core part of how we do things, especially if you count the vast majority who hardly use facebook.
i didn't think there is a big difference in IT culture when it comes to normal users, they all use almost the same service and may be in the same way
oh, you are right about the media

Use is not the same really, in Australia for example, more and more government services are done online. If you cannot use a computer (a senior for example, an old person), you can go to a public library and find a volunteer, or go to the government office, just to find a person who will, guess what, help you use the online system!

yeah, this will make more people care about it
but i was talking about the users here who are already using the internet, i think they all will care about changing their facebook password if they know it might be stolen

i think both, your and my point are right
- the culture, and how much people care about it and feel that some parts of their lives depend on it
- and the amount of information presented to whom are already care in their mother language

I may be outdated on this, but I think the amount of online shopping and other sensitive activities requiring SSL is much less (pretty much anything beyond facebook -without factoring security concerns-, youtube, and chat), or at least the perception of it is being less. Admittedly not an expert on the topic though.
